Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A routine audit is scheduled far ahead, leaving ample time to update documentation
Story: I watched my younger brother strap on his helmet, eyes shining with excitement as he eyed the steep, uneven ramp in our backyard. He was determined to master a new skateboard trick, but the ramp’s cracks and loose boards made my stomach twist. As his sibling, I wanted to cheer him on, but I also felt a deep responsibility to keep him safe. At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder about the upcoming safety audit at work. As an engineer, I knew I had plenty of time to update the documentation, but the expectation to uphold safety standards was ingrained in me. I found myself torn—should I focus on my brother, maybe even stop him, or trust his judgment and use this time to get ahead on my audit prep? The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my attention, each with its own definition of safety. I stood there, heart pounding, caught between the urge to protect my brother and the pull of my professional duty.
